newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia winning battle against crime, minister says.
newsitem.headline: Russia winning battle against crime, minister says.

text.p: Russia, plagued by a breakdown in law and order after the fall of communism, is now winning the battle against crime, Interior Minister Anatoly Kulikov said on Tuesday.
"Despite the difficulties of the transition period, the criminal situation is under control," Kulikov said during a meeting with British Home Secretary Michael Howard.
He said overall crime fell 4.7 percent in 1996, with 2.6 million registered crimes. The total number of murders last year -- 29,406 -- fell below 30,000 for the first time in several years, he said.
"We are completely satisfied that the number of serious crimes, including murder, was down 10.5 percent," he said.
Kulikov, speaking briefly in front of reporters at the start of the meeting, made no mention of the high-profile criminal groups which appear to operate at will in Russia.
A series of murders -- such as the apparent contract killing of a prominent American businessman at the entrance to a Moscow subway -- remains unsolved.
Many crimes, including rape, go unreported because victims consider it futile to turn to the authorities.

But Kulikov commended the work of the police and said 75 percent of all murders were solved. "This allows us to conclude that most regional internal affairs organs are highly capable and professional," he said.
He said, however, that crime increased in 18 regions of Russia, especially in the northern Caucasus which he said was partially related to the turmoil in separatist Chechnya.
